sect1.title: Monitoring Network Performance
sect1.para: Table 30–1 describes the commands that are available for monitoring network performance.

entry.para: Command
Description
Look at the response of hosts on the network.
Test the reliability of your packet sizes. This command can tell you whether the network is delaying packets or dropping packets.
Capture packets from the network and trace the calls from each client to each server.

sect2.title: How to Check the Response of Hosts on the Network
sect2.para: Check the response of hosts on the network with the ping command.

itemizedlist.para: If you suspect a physical problem, you can use ping to find the response time of several hosts on the network. If the response from one host is not what you would expect, you can investigate that host. Physical problems could be caused by the following:

sect2.para: For more information about this command, see ping1M.

example.title: Checking the Response of Hosts on the Network
example.para: The simplest version of ping sends a single packet to a host on the network. If ping receives the correct response, the command prints the message host is alive.
With the s option, ping sends one datagram per second to a host. The command then prints each response and the time that was required for the round trip. An example follows.
example.screen:
$ ping -s pluto 64 bytes from pluto (123.456.78.90): icmp_seq=0. time=3.82 ms 64 bytes from pluto (123.456.78.90): icmp_seq=5. time=0.947 ms 64 bytes from pluto (123.456.78.90): icmp_seq=6. time=0.855 ms ^C ----pluto PING Statistics---- 3 packets transmitted, 3 packets received, 0% packet loss
round-trip (ms) min/avg/max/sttdev = 0.855/1.87/3.82/1.7

sect2.title: How to Send Packets to Hosts on the Network
sect2.para: Test the reliability of your packet sizes with the spray command.

listitem.para: Number of microseconds to pause between sending packets. If you do not use a delay, you might deplete the buffers.
Is the system to send packets.

sect2.para: For more information about this command, see spray1M.

example.title: Sending Packets to Hosts on the Network
example.para: The following example sends 100 packets to a host (-c 100), with a packet size of 2048 bytes (-l 2048). The packets are sent with a delay time of 20 microseconds between each burst (-d 20).
example.screen: $ spray -c 100 -d 20 -l 2048 pluto sending 100 packets of length 2048 to pluto ... no packets dropped by pluto 279 packets/sec, 573043 bytes/sec

sect2.title: How to Capture Packets From the Network
sect2.para: To capture packets from the network and trace the calls from each client to each server, use snoop. This command provides accurate timestamps that enable some network performance problems to be isolated quickly. For more information, see snoop1M.
Dropped packets could be caused by insufficient buffer space or an overloaded CPU.

sect2.title: How to Check the Network Status
sect2.para: To display network status information, such as statistics about the state of network interfaces, routing tables, and various protocols, use the netstat command.

listitem.para: Displays the state of the TCP/IP interfaces
Displays statistics for the UDP, TCP, ICMP, and IGMP protocols

sect3.title: Examples–Checking the Network Status
sect3.para: The following example shows output from the netstat -i command, which displays the state of the interfaces that are used for TCP/IP traffic.
sect3.screen: $ netstat -i Name Mtu Net/Dest Address Ipkts Ierrs Opkts Oerrs Collis Queue lo0 8232 software localhost 1280 0 1280 0 0 0 eri0 1500 loopback venus 1628480 0 347070 16 39354 0
sect3.para: This display shows the number of packets that a machine has transmitted and has received on each interface. A machine with active network traffic should show both Ipkts and Opkts continually increasing.

Calculate the network collisions rate by dividing the number of collision counts (Collis) by the number of out packets (Opkts). In the previous example, the collision rate is 11 percent. A network-wide collision rate that is greater than 5 to 10 percent can indicate a problem.

Calculate the error rate for the input packets by dividing the number of input errors by the total number of input packets (Ierrs/Ipkts). The error rate for the output packets is the number of output errors divided by the total number of output packets (Oerrs/Opkts). If the input error rate is high, at over 0.25 percent, the host might be dropping packets.

sect2.title: How to Display NFS Server and Client Statistics
sect2.para: The NFS distributed file service uses a remote procedure call (RPC) facility that translates local commands into requests for the remote host. The remote procedure calls are synchronous. The client application is blocked or suspended until the server has completed the call and has returned the results. One of the major factors that affects NFS performance is the retransmission rate.

itemizedlist.para: If the file server cannot respond to a client's request, the client retransmits the request a specified number of times before the client quits. Each retransmission imposes system overhead and increases network traffic. Excessive retransmissions can cause network performance problems. If the retransmission rate is high, you could look for the following:

listitem.para: Overloaded servers that complete requests too slowly
An Ethernet interface that is dropping packets
Network congestion, which slows the packet transmission

sect2.para: Table 30–3 describes the nfsstat options to display client and server statistics.

entry.para: Command
Display
Client statistics
Server statistics
Network statistics for each file system

sect2.para: Use nfsstat -c to show client statistics, and nfsstat -s to show server statistics. Use netstat -m to display network statistics for each file system. For more information, see nfsstat1M.

sect3.para: If you suspect that the hardware components of your network are creating problems, you need to look closely at the cabling and connectors.
